author: shinayser
body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When I run the command:
```
PS C:\Users\shina> Update-Help -UICulture en-us
```

I get the following error:

```
Update-Help: Failed to update Help for the module(s) 'Dism, Get-NetView, Kds, NetQos, PcsvDevice, PKI, PSReadline, Whea
WindowsUpdate' with UI culture(s) {en-US} : One or more errors occurred. (Response status code does not indicate success: 404 (The specified blob does not exist.).).
English-US help content is available and can be installed using: Update-Help -UICulture en-US.
```

As you can see I am already forcing `en-us` local. And yes, I am invoking the command on a administrator terminal.

### Expected behavior

```console
I expected to be updated properly.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Update-Help: Failed to update Help for the module(s) 'Dism, Get-NetView, Kds, NetQos, PcsvDevice, PKI, PSReadline, Whea
WindowsUpdate' with UI culture(s) {en-US} : One or more errors occurred. (Response status code does not indicate success: 404 (The specified blob does not exist.).).
English-US help content is available and can be installed using: Update-Help -UICulture en-US.
```
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
```


### Visuals

_No response_

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body: @sdwheeler can you please take a look?

comments.author: sdwheeler
comments.body:
Those modules all have known issues. The PSReadline problem is well documented in the blog. https://devblogs.microsoft.com/powershell/updating-help-for-the-psreadline-module-in-windows-powershell-5-1/
PowerShell Team
Updating help for the PSReadLine module in Windows PowerShell 5.1
Back in November of 2020 I posted instructions about how to work around the problem of updating the help for the PSReadLine module. The version of the PSReadline module that shipped in Windows PowerShell 5.1 used a lowercase letter in the name.

comments.author: shinayser
comments.body:
Thanks for your answer @sdwheeler. Taking a look at the article, I could figure out one small thing you said on it:
`Close all powershell.exe processes. Then rename the PSReadline module folder name to PSReadLine.`

What you mean about renaming the module folder? What folder? Where can I find that folders?
_Sorry asking but I am newbiee in powershell right now and I just started my studies recently._

comments.author: sdwheeler
comments.body:
You can find the folder using:

```
Get-Module -ListAvailable PSReadline | Select-Object Path
```

comments.author: shinayser
comments.body:
Interesting... the only PsReadline with lower case I got installed is from the old "Windows Powershell" isntalation I got. I am using "Powershell 7.1.2" to update the help. Maybe thats a bug?

```
# That one is ok
C:\program files\windowsapps\microsoft.powershell_7.2.1.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe\Modules\PSReadLine\PSReadLine.psd1

# That one is lower case
C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\PSReadline\2.0.0\PSReadline.psd1 
```

comments.author: adamobrennan
comments.body:
@sdwheeler I have received a similar error when running the same command, and any variation on it I could find when googling this issue:

`Update-Help: Failed to update Help for the module(s) 'PSReadline' with UI culture(s) {en-US} : One or more errors occurred. (Response status code does not indicate success: 404 (The specified blob does not exist.).).
English-US help content is available and can be installed using: Update-Help -UICulture en-US.`

I tried the workaround you wrote in the URL above on a fresh install of 7.2.1 yesterday, but my folder had the correct capitalization: PSReadLine. So I tried it the incorrect way (how it is capitalized in the error, I noticed): PSReadline. Still no dice.

comments.author: adamobrennan
comments.body: I figured mine out - I added my Module folder to my PSModulePath in my system environment variables and it resolved my issue. When I got my error it was because it was looking at the Windows PowerShell 5.1 that came with my computer, where @sdwheeler is right and I had the documented issue going on as well. Hope any of this has been helpful, good luck @shinayser

comments.author: joegyamfi31
comments.body: @adamobrennan, could you please show how you added your Module folder to your PSModulePath in your system environment? I had similar issue. Thanks.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body:
> Interesting... the only PsReadline with lower case I got installed is from the old "Windows Powershell" isntalation I got. I am using "Powershell 7.1.2" to update the help. Maybe thats a bug?

@shinayser FYI, the `PSReadLine` folder name for Windows PowerShell has been fixed in the latest Windows 10 (fix checked in in March 2021).

comments.author: msftbot[bot]
comments.body: This issue has been marked as answered and has not had any activity for **1 day**. It has been closed for housekeeping purposes.

comments.author: Remzi1993
comments.body:
> This issue has been marked as answered and has not had any activity for **1 day**. It has been closed for housekeeping purposes.

This issue is still very much relevant. I also got the same error. This shouldn't be happening on a production ready product. (And it's worse, because I'm on Windows 11 - you wouldn't expect this since it (some of the errors) was supposedly fixed in Windows 10)

title: Update-Help returns error (error 404?)
